**IDE**

Download and install **IntelliJ**.

Use[ https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/download/](https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/download/) 

Accept defaults and then open up intelliJ. Your first project will be a simple console app. 

Watch the videos for instructions and fuller explanations.

Rename - using **refactor->rename** - the Main class - this is also the name of the .java file to:

**program.java** 

Warning: if you rename without using the **refactor->rename **your code might not work. 

**main()**

The **public static void main** is the **entry point **for your program/application you build. Whenever you execute your console based java code it runs this function. 

**Console output**

You should create your first project`. `You should have the following:

This is the syntax of code to output to the console:


```
System.out.println("hello world");
```


Insert this code into the correct place and run it. 

Output:

run:
hello world
BUILD SUCCESSFUL (total time: 0 seconds)

**Explore** Here are some simple variations and problems to extend the example given above.
1 How do you glue together different strings in a System.out.println() statement?

Try each of the following:

  1. System.out.println("My name is " + "Nadim");
  2. System.out.println("My name is " & "Nadim");

    Which one works?

2 How do you insert a separate value from a variable into a System.out.println() statement?

Use the following in your code*:

String name = "Anna";

How would you place that in a System.out.println() statement? Try each of the following:

  1. System.out.println("My name is " + name);
  2. System.out.println("My name is " , name);
  3. System.out.println("My name is " & name);

    Which one works?
We begin with the following simple program:

In Java, unlike Python (for example) if you want to store a piece of information you have to tell the environment what **type **of information you want to store. 


```
int age;
```


This line of code stores whole numbers (integers or as we say in Java: **int**). We attach a label to this data: **age**. We can then hold values in it:


```
age = 18;
```


We can, of course, do both steps in one line of code:


```
int age = 18;
```

We will be using a **scanner** mechanism for getting input from the user. 

You will need to add the following statement at the top of any file that uses this code:


```
import java.util.Scanner;
```


Copy the following code and execute[^1]

**Explanation of code** To accept input from the user we use a scanner object: ``` Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in); ``` These lines create a scanner object. We can then use this **input object variable to get input from the console. This input object variable does not allow you to prompt the user. We have to pair the input with a System.out.println line: ``` System.out.println("Please enter a string: "); String inString = input.nextLine(); ``` When asking the console for text input we use a method called `nextLine()`. We then pass this to a variable `inString.` Finally, we display what was inputted. ``` System.out.println("You entered string "+ inString); ``` **Explore** Using the following template:
